title: 109_hr135
content: The "Twenty-First Century Water Commission Act of 2005" establishes a commission to address the increasing stress on the nation's water resources. The commission's duties include assessing technological and economic advances to increase water supplies and developing a comprehensive strategy for sustainable water availability. The Commission established by the "Twenty-First Century Water Commission Act of 2005" is tasked with conducting water assessments, studying water management programs, and developing recommendations for a comprehensive water strategy that respects the primary role of States in regulating water rights and uses. The Commission established by the "Twenty-First Century Water Commission Act of 2005" is tasked with identifying incentives for a reliable water supply for the next 50 years, suggesting strategies to avoid additional mandates on State and local governments, eliminating duplication among Federal programs, optimizing water supply reliability and quality, capturing excess water for conservation, and proposing financing options for water management projects. The Commission suggests strategies for conserving water supplies, including repairing aging infrastructure, and other objectives for effective water management to ensure reliability, availability, and quality. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 9 members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The President appoints 5 members, the Speaker of the House appoints 2 members, and the Majority Leader of the Senate appoints 2 members. Members must have expertise in water policy and cannot hold any other position in the government while serving on the Commission. The Commission members, appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, represent diverse perspectives. The President designates the Chairperson, and members serve for the Commission's lifespan. Vacancies are filled as per original appointment rules. Members serve without compensation but receive travel expenses. Members of the Commission receive travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence, as per applicable provisions. SEC. 6. MEETINGS AND QUORUM. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 60 days of all members being appointed and additional meetings as needed. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for conducting business. SEC. 7. DIRECTOR AND STAFF. The Director of the Commission is appointed by the Speaker of the House and the Majority Leader of the Senate, in consultation with relevant committees. The Director and staff are paid at a rate not exceeding GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Commission's powers and proceedings are outlined in Section 8. The Commission shall hold at least 10 hearings, including one in Washington, D.C., and others in different regions of the U.S. to gather diverse testimony on water issues. Federal agencies must provide information and support upon request within 30 days. The Commission must provide necessary information within 30 days of request and detail personnel for temporary duty as needed to carry out the provisions of the Act. SEC. 9. REPORTS. The Commission is required to provide interim reports every 6 months to the President and relevant congressional committees, detailing progress and activities. A final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation must be submitted within 3 years of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission is mandated to submit findings and conclusions to the President and specific congressional committees. The Commission will terminate within 30 days of submitting the final report. $9,000,000 is authorized for the Act.
